awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Balancing flocs and granules for activated sludge process intensification: Stoke's vs Fick's Laws
awd_abstract_narration:
1512667
Sturm

Municipal wastewater treatment plants are under increasing pressure to meet low discharge limits for nitrogen and phosphorus, while aging infrastructure and changing precipitation patterns causes a wet weather burden. A new process, referred to as granular sludge applications, offers a solution to these challenges since slow-growing microbial populations capable of nutrient removal are maintained in dense particles that can be retained under high loading and flow conditions. In the proposed research, settling of the particles will be determined for an optimum granule diameter and density will be investigated and criteria to select for desired particles will be developed.

To date, granular sludge units have been pioneered in Europe using column-type sequencing batch reactors that utilize a fast settling time and continuous washout of biomass in order to maintain granular sludge, typically resulting in high effluent suspended solids. This reactor geometry and dependence on internal settling selection limits the adoption of granular technology by existing wastewater treatment plants, which have a tremendous infrastructure already built that should be utilized as plants expand. This proposal is framing sludge particle formation and selection in terms of balancing Fick?s and Stoke?s Law. The PIs hypothesize that low-strength municipal wastewater can supply a minimum organic surface loading of readily-biodegradable substrate required for extracellular polymeric substances and granule formation, as well as the selection of phosphorus accumulating organisms, when a fermentation pretreatment is performed. While current research on granular formation focuses on selecting granular sludge and out-selecting flocs, the PIs hypothesize that: 1) balancing the two sludge structures will provide the maximum reactor performance, and 2) the application of external settling selectors to preferentially retain good settling biomass and PAOs will alleviate the high effluent suspended solids burden typical of column-type granular reactors, and stabilize biological phosphorus removal. The research has the potential to transform the US water sector by developing approaches for granular sludge within existing infrastructure. The proposed project will center on promoting industry-utility-university partnerships to the wastewater profession. DC Water and Hampton Roads Sanitation District have been early adopters of granular sludge technology within the United States, having performed anammox granule pilot research for the past five years at their wastewater treatment plants. The Co-PIs will develop a Water Environment Federation workshop that promotes utility-university partnerships, highlighting how these hasten new technology adoption.

por.por_cntn:
Municipal wastewater treatment plants are under increasing pressure to meet low discharge limits for nitrogen and phosphorus, while aging infrastructure and changing precipitation patterns create a wet weather burden. Granular sludge applications offer a solution to these challenges since slow-growing microbial populations capable of nutrient removal are maintained in dense particles that can be retained under high loading and flow conditions. The main objective of this research was to develop design criteria to induce granulation in existing continuous flow activated sludge processes. A secondary objective was to promote university-industry partnerships that can hasten the demonstration and adoption of innovative wastewater treatment technologies in the United States. To date, granular sludge units have been built using column-type sequencing batch reactors that have feast and famine substrate gradients. In this project, we hypothesized that granules can be selected in a plug flow bioreactor configuration when the influent wastewater has a minimum fraction of readily biodegradable COD (rbCOD) to initiate granule formation, and settling selection is applied to retain granules while wasting flocs.

 

Pilot wastewater reactors were operated by undergraduate and graduate students at municipal facilities in Lawrence, Kansas and Washington DC (DC Water). Additional full-scale data was provided by Hampton Roads Sanitation District (HRSD). Results from the Lawrence pilots showed that granule formation is stimulated with an F:M ratio of 0.2 g rbCOD per g biomass per day (g VSS-d). This research was first presented at the Water Environment Federation's (WEF) annual conference in 2017. A PhD student incorporated a kinetic function for the formation of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) as a response to substrate uptake rate, and this model was calibrated with the pilot data in commercial wastewater simulation software. This research provides a fundamental understanding of how substrate availability stimulates EPS and biofilm formation. We have converted the overall F:M ratio of 0.20 g rbCOD/g VSS-d to an anaerobic F:M guidance of 2.5 g COD/g MLSS-d. The value is in agreement with full-scale observations of granule formation in continuous flow systems. Overall, through this collaborative research, we have proposed design guidelines that can be immediately used by wastewater process engineers to enable granulation and intensification of current facilities.

 

A second major hypothesis of this project was that balanced granular and flocculent sludge can be maintained within an existing continuous flow activated sludge process using external selectors. Using case study data from full-scale sidestream deammonification systems with hydrocyclones (DEMON) and hydrocyclones installed on mainstream systems (inDENSE), a graduate student working at DC Water modeled the balance between an organism?s net growth rate and its washout rate. This model applies a general framework for intelligent design and operation of external selectors, such as screens or hydrocyclones. Our publication demonstrates how the washout rate can be controlled with these units to selectively retain functional microorganisms in the system. In a separate paper, we explore the limitations to floc formation in high-rate activated sludge systems. This work aimed to address a common concern by operators that when SVIs are very low (indicating granulation), effluent suspended solids can be high. The research provides a framework for how collision efficiency and floc strength work together to create efficient clarifier performance. We explore how EPS composition influences collision efficiency, while total EPS amount influences floc strength. Key aspects of the intellectual merit of this project are the kinetic model for EPS formation as a function of substrate uptake rate, and a theoretical framework for how EPS composition and quantity affect both floc strength and collision efficiency within a clarifier.

 

The Broader Impacts of this project center around promoting industry-utility-university partnerships to the wastewater profession. This research has been presented at major scientific conferences nationally and internationally: WEFTEC (every year of the project), International Water Association (IWA) Granular Sludge (2018), WEF Nutrient Removal (2017,2019), and IWA Resource Recovery (2017). We also presented to state member association conferences for WEF in Kansas, Virginia, and Florida. The PI presented seminars to several consulting firms (Black & Veatch, GHD, CDM Smith, Burns and McDonnell). During the life of the project, several engineering firms began adopting hydrocyclones and anaerobic selectors to encourage sludge densification, and the results from this project were actively discussed with many industrial collaborators.

 

The project provided research opportunities for four female graduate students at KU and five undergraduate students. In addition, many students working at DC Water and HRSD participated in project discussions and data collection.  Dr. Sturm, a female associate professor at the beginning of the project, was promoted to full professor. She was also elected to serve as the Chair of the IWA's USA National Committee and is Vice-Chair of WEF's Municipal Design Symposia. Research partnerships with the City of Lawrence were sustained after this project ended.
